COVID-19 negative certification required for entering the country.
Upon arrival in Ecuador, all passengers will be required to complete a Health Declaration Form with their itinerary and local contact details. You must also present a negative Real-Time Polymerase Chain Reaction (RT-PCR) qualitative test for COVID-19, taken up to 72 hours prior to boarding your flight to Ecuador.
From 1 December 2021, anyone over 16 years old must present their full COVID-19 vaccination certificate (i.e. both doses for those vaccinations which consist of two doses), received at least 14 days prior the flight date, and a negative RT-PCR test, taken up to 72 hours prior to boarding their flight.
Passengers from 2 to 15 years old (11 months and 29 days) must present a negative RT-PCR test, taken 72 hours before the flight.
Only children under 2 years old are exempt from the RT-PCR test or the COVID-19 vaccination certificate requirement.
From India: All passengers arriving from India, even if they have only transited the countries, must present a negative RT-PCR test, taken up to 72 hours prior to boarding their flight, regardless of whether they are fully vaccinated or not.
In response to the new variant ‘Omicron’, from 1 December 2021, all passengers arriving from or transiting through South Africa, Botswana, Egypt, Mozambique, Lesotho, Zimbabwe, Eswantini (Swaziland) and Namibia will not be allowed to enter the country.
From USA: From 8 January 2022, passengers travelling from the USA, who are residents in Ecuador, can travel without a RT-PCR negative test given the high demand and constraints to access this test in this country. However, passengers who cannot get this test have to present their full COVID-19 vaccination certificate, received at least 14 days before their flight date. On arrival in Ecuador, these passengers will be required to get a RT-PCR test, at their own expense, and to follow mandatory self-isolation for 14 days. This measure will be enforced until 16 January.
Passengers arriving from countries whose regulations state that COVID-19 vaccination is available only after 6 months of having been infected, and who are thus unable to show their full vaccination certificate, will be required to present an official document proving this regulation (valid for 6 months) and a negative RT-PCR test.
*Travel to and from the Galapagos: All travellers over 16 years old wishing to enter the Islands must present a negative Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) test for COVID-19, taken up to 72 hours prior to the date of the flight to the Galapagos Islands along with a full COVID-19 vaccination certificate (i.e. both doses for those vaccinations which consist of two doses, or its equivalent), received at least 14 days prior the flight date. However, the use of “Immunity Certificates or Vaccination Certificates/Cards” from foreign passengers will be subject to constant review.
Children between 2 and 16 years must present a negative RT-PCR test for COVID-19, taken up to 72 hours prior embarking the flight.

Latest news:

International Restrictions:
*Entry to Ecuador: The land border with Peru remains closed. However, Ecuadorean nationals and foreign residents may be allowed to enter Ecuador, via the Huaquillas southern border checkpoint. The land border with Colombia opened on the 16 December to all travellers, but only through the ‘Rumichaca’ international checkpoint, from 8am to 5pm.
Most ports remain closed for travel/tourism activities. Only cargo services are allowed. As of October 2021, international cruise ship operations are permitted in Esmeraldas, Guayaquil, Manta and Puerto Baquerizo ports.
As of 1 June 2020, international commercial flights have resumed operations to and from Ecuador. However, following the identification of a new variant of Coronavirus, we highly recommend you to contact your airline/travel company to check your travel itinerary.
As of October 2021, international cruise ship operations are authorised at the following ports: Esmeraldas, Manta, Guayaquil and Puerto Bolivar. However, there are strict guidelines and measures to comply with to obtain the relevant permissions from the competent Ecuadorean authorities.
*Testing / screening on arrival: Upon arrival in Ecuador, all passengers will be required to complete a Health Declaration Form with their itinerary and local contact details. You must also present a negative Real-Time Polymerase Chain Reaction (RT-PCR) qualitative test for COVID-19, taken up to 72 hours prior to boarding your flight to Ecuador. This is a mandatory requirement, which airlines are responsible for enforcing in order to allow passengers to board.
From 1 December 2021, anyone over 16 years old must present their full COVID-19 vaccination certificate (i.e. both doses for those vaccinations which consist of two doses), received at least 14 days prior the flight date, and a negative RT-PCR test, taken up to 72 hours prior to boarding their flight.
Passengers from 2 to 15 years old (11 months and 29 days) must present a negative RT-PCR test, taken 72 hours before the flight.
The use of “Immunity Certificates or Vaccination Certificates/Cards” from foreign passengers will be subject to constant review. See Demonstrating your COVID-19 status
Passengers in transit are subject to the submission of the above COVID-19 test and vaccination card. You should arrange to take a private test.
Only children under 2 years old are exempt from the RT-PCR test or the COVID-19 vaccination certificate requirement. Airline crew members are not subject to the above requirements as long as they are not staying overnight in the country.
If, on arrival, a passenger presents COVID-19 related symptoms, they will be required to take a RT-PCR test. If the result is positive, passengers will be instructed to self isolate for 14 days.
All passengers arriving from India, even if they have only transited the countries, must present a negative RT-PCR test, taken up to 72 hours prior to boarding their flight, regardless of whether they are fully vaccinated or not. These passengers must self isolate for 10 days either in a private home or in a hotel, at their own expense. The Ministry of Public Health (MSP) is responsible for following up this requirement.
In response to the new variant ‘Omicron’, from 1 December 2021, all passengers arriving from or transiting through South Africa, Botswana, Egypt, Mozambique, Lesotho, Zimbabwe, Eswantini (Swaziland) and Namibia will not be allowed to enter the country.
From 8 January 2022, passengers travelling from the USA, who are residents in Ecuador, can travel without a RT-PCR negative test given the high demand and constraints to access this test in this country. However, passengers who cannot get this test have to present their full COVID-19 vaccination certificate, received at least 14 days before their flight date. On arrival in Ecuador, these passengers will be required to get a RT-PCR test, at their own expense, and to follow mandatory self-isolation for 14 days. This measure will be enforced until 16 January.
Passengers arriving from countries whose regulations state that COVID-19 vaccination is available only after 6 months of having been infected, and who are thus unable to show their full vaccination certificate, will be required to present an official document proving this regulation (valid for 6 months) and a negative RT-PCR test.
*Demonstrating your COVID-19 status: Ecuador will accept proof of COVID-19 recovery and vaccination record and proof of COVID-19 vaccination issued in the Crown Dependencies. Your appointment card from vaccination centres is not designed to be used as proof of vaccination and should not be used to demonstrate your vaccine status.
*Quarantine requirements: Passengers who test positive in the antigen test taken at the airport will need to self-isolate for 10 days, from the date of the test. Self-isolation for non-residents can be carried out in any hotel, at their own expense. The full address of where the passenger will self-isolate should be included in the Health Status Declaration Form.
Local residents and people qualified as “priority attention groups” such as people over 65 years old, children and pregnant women, will be allowed to self-isolate at their homes. The Ministry of Public Health has published more information on coronavirus protocols that also allows for direct messaging with the Ministry (Spanish only).
If you need to find emergency accommodation to go through the mandatory self-isolation protocol, you can access options on the Ministry of Public Health website. The Government will monitor the situation in other countries with high risk of contagion to prevent incoming flights.
*Travel to and from the Galapagos: Tourist activities are allowed in the Galapagos Islands. Commercial flights connecting the Islands resumed on 3 August 2020. The local authorities created a ‘safe travel corridor’ for travel to the Galapagos Islands.
All travellers over 16 years old wishing to enter the Islands must present a negative Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) test for COVID-19, taken up to 72 hours prior to the date of the flight to the Galapagos Islands along with a full COVID-19 vaccination certificate (i.e. both doses for those vaccinations which consist of two doses, or its equivalent), received at least 14 days prior the flight date. However, the use of “Immunity Certificates or Vaccination Certificates/Cards” from foreign passengers will be subject to constant review. See ‘Demonstrating your COVID-19 status’
Children between 2 and 16 years must present a negative RT-PCR test for COVID-19, taken up to 72 hours prior embarking the flight.
Any passengers presenting COVID-19 related symptoms will be denied entry to the Islands, and a Ministry of Public Health team will activate the relevant protocols.
National and foreign tourists must also present evidence of a return flight, as well as the Galapagos Transit Control Card, to be filled out online at least 24 hours before the flight. There is no longer a requirement for a safe passage document (‘salvoconducto’). Travel health insurance is mandatory for foreign tourists. For inter-island travel, all passengers over 12 years must present their complete vaccination certificate.


Internal Restrictions:
*Travel in Ecuador: The Ecuadorean government provides coronavirus-related information on the Coronavirus Ecuador website. The Ministry of Public Health (MSP) also provides an information page. However, the most up to date information is accessible via their Twitter account.
*Public spaces and services: Power to impose traffic restrictions, curfew hours and controls on social gatherings lies with local municipalities and other competent authorities, in conjunction with Ecuador’s National Emergency Operations Committee (COE).
Please check more detailed information with local authorities – details below - to ensure that you comply with any local restrictions, including vehicle circulation restrictions in your area.
The general nationwide biosecurity measures include:
• extra precaution advised for people over 60 years old, and those whose medical conditions make them vulnerable to COVID-19
• mandatory use of face masks in public spaces
• all individuals to comply with social distancing measures and practice frequent hand washing
• in-person school classes were suspended in 2020. However, voluntary blended classes (mix of in-person and online) have been progressively allowed to take place, since 7 June 2021, if the school’s COVID action plan has been properly approved by the National Emergency Operations Committee (COE)
• remote working continues to be encouraged
• the reopening of beaches will continue to be monitored via the “Distancia2” app
• authorised labs to undertake COVID-19 tests
• a nationwide tracing app ( ̔ASI Ecuador̕ ) is available to alert people if they have been in contact with a confirmed COVID-19 case during the last 15 days. The app is supported via Bluetooth and maintains the confidentiality of users
• the land border with Peru remains closed until further notice. However, Ecuadorean nationals and foreign residents may be allowed to enter Ecuador via the Rumichaca and the Huaquillas northern and southern border checkpoints
• the land border with Colombia (Rumichaca) opened on 17 December 2021 to all travellers, but only through the ‘Rumichaca’ international check-point, from 8am to 5pm. You are required to present your COVID-19 complete dose vaccination card and a negative PCR test result
• most ports remain closed for travel/tourism activities. Only cargo services are allowed. As of October 2021, international cruise ship operations are permitted in Esmeraldas, Guayaquil, Manta and Puerto Baquerizo ports
• mandatory COVID-19 vaccination for Ecuadorean nationals and foreign residents
Since the beginning of January 2022, Ecuador’s National Emergency Operations Committee (COE) have urged local municipalities to implement the following measures until 23 January 2022:
• maximum public attendance capacity of 75% in fairs, shopping centres, markets, supermarkets (in addition only one person per family may enter at a time), museums and financial and government establishments;
• maximum public attendance capacity of 50% in restaurants, food courts, places of worship, entrepreneurship fairs, cinemas and theatres, gyms, thermal baths and spas; the selling and consumption of food and drinks at cinemas and theatres is not permitted;
• closure of bars, clubs and convention centres, and prohibition of public and private events, including: receptions, concerts, processions and religious events in public spaces;
• strict compliance with biosecurity protocols, use of face mask, frequent hand-washing, appropriate ventilation and social distancing;
• local governments which have beaches/bathing areas to establish a maximum public attendance capacity of 75% and opening hours of 06:00 until 18:00;
• the National Sanitary Authority has issued a regulation requiring all people over 12 (including foreign tourists) to present their COVID-19 vaccination card (showing 2 complete doses) to enter any establishment that attends the public for non-essential services (for example, but not limited to, banks, shops, supermarkets, restaurants, transport, etc). This rule has been also enforced at airports. This will not apply to public sector institutions and for essential services such as health and education. The national police will be in charge of enforcement together with any relevant local authority;
• increasing of transport frequencies to 100%
• from 4 to 23 January 2022, maximum capacity of 50% for in-person working, except from strategic sectors. Same recommendation for private entities
• as of 17 January 2022, transport operators will be responsible for enforcing the mandatory presentation of COVID-19 vaccination certificates from all passengers over 5 years old, for all inter-district, interstate, urban and tourist buses. Random checks will be implemented by municipal governments and the National Transport Agency (ANT)
Please note that the power to impose these restrictions rests with local authorities, and the COE may only make recommendations. As a result, you may see some discrepancies between local areas (see advice for Quito below).
Please check more detailed information with local authorities – details below - to ensure that you comply with any local restrictions, including vehicle circulation restrictions in your area.
*Restrictions: The central government´s ‘red, yellow, green’ alert system has been reinstated (‘Semáforo de Protección COVID-19 ’) as an internal management tool for epidemiological and risk monitoring, and will recommend relevant restrictions for high, medium and low risk levels. The district traffic light colours will change weekly. Red restrictions for 17 to 23 January are as follows:
• maximum public attendance capacity of 30%, with restricted hours, in shopping centres, supermarkets, markets, financial and government establishments, public transport, restaurants, bars, cinemas, theatres, gyms, thermal baths, spas and higher education establishments. Controlled activities with 30% maximum attendance at beaches, parks and open spaces. Protected areas and national parks will be closed from Monday to Wednesday, and accessible from Thursday to Sunday but within restricted hours
• suspended preschool education
• online classes for primary school education
Yellow:
• maximum public attendance capacity of 50% in shopping centres, supermarkets, markets, financial and government establishments, public transport, restaurants, bars, cinemas, theatres, gyms, thermal baths, spas, beaches, parks, open spaces and higher education establishments
• suspended preschool education
• hybrid classes for primary school education
Green:
• maximum public attendance capacity of 75% in shopping centres, supermarkets, markets, financial and government establishments, public transport, restaurants, bars, cinemas, theatres, gyms, thermal baths and spas, beaches, parks, open spaces and high education establishments
• preschool education aligned to the Ministry of Education’s protocol
• in-person primary school education
Each municipal government is responsible for determining its own specific restrictions including, but not limited to, maximum capacity for public transport, the circulation of private vehicles against licence plate numbers, health prevention protocols for all businesses and industries and alcohol sale and consumption.
We strongly recommend that you follow the local municipalities’ social media channels to obtain the most up to date notifications, but bear in mind that these might change at any time:
Quito: @MunicipioQuito; Guayaquil: @alcaldiagye; Cuenca: @MunicipioCuenca; Galapagos: @CGGalapagos
Ecuador’s National Emergency Operations Committee (COE) has a website with their official resolutions (Spanish only).
Within the national health emergency, the Ecuadorean Ministry of Health will continue to issue the required health prevention measures, including PCR tests and any mandatory self-isolation (Aislamiento Preventivo Obligatorio – APO) requirements.
*Restrictions in Quito: Quito Municipality continues with its campaign to increase testing and triage. In addition to adhering to the standard general biosecurity measures, you must also carry an identity card at all times.
All COVID-19 measures will continue to be enforced robustly and infringements will be handled by the relevant competent authorities.
The “Hoy No Circula” circulation private vehicle restriction system is no longer in place; the former “Pico y Placa” system was reinstated from 4 November 2021.
Vehicles with number plates ending in the following numbers will have restrictions on the given days below, and will not be allowed to circulate from 6am to 9.30pm and from 4pm to 9pm on the assigned days: Monday: 0, 1; Tuesday: 2, 3; Wednesday 4, 5; Thursday 6, 7 and Friday 8, 9.
There are no vehicle restrictions to circulate at the weekends and on official public holidays.
Special safe passage documents (“salvoconductos”) are no longer valid and cannot be used during “Pico y Placa”. However, “Pico y Placa” does not apply to over 65 year-olds who drive their own vehicle.
Visit the Quito “Mariscal Sucre” International Airport website for details on their COVID-19 protocols and health measures for passengers.
Visit the Guayaquil “Jose Joaquin de Olmedo” International Airport website for general information on COVID-19 measures and related FAQ (in Spanish).
